title: Our companies must not cross "bright red line" on corruption: Temasek Holdings
text:
India Our companies must not cross "bright red line" on corruption: Temasek Holdings Taking aim at corporate corruption, this message from Temasek chairman Lim Boon Heng comes after the offshore rig-building unit of Keppel paid more than $422 million to resolve charges that it bribed Brazilian officials. "In markets where practices are questionable and compromising integrity is required to win business or contracts, we have to be very clear — there is a bright red line our companies should not cross," Lim said. Published 7 Hours Ago Roslan Rahman | AFP | Getty Images The Temasek Holding company sign in Singapore on July 8, 2010. 
Taking aim at corporate corruption, Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings called on firms it has stakes in not to cross a "bright red line" in the wake of a bribery scandal at one of its portfolio companies Keppel Corporation . 
The message from chairman Lim Boon Heng to major portfolio companies comes after the offshore rig-building unit of Keppel — in which Temasek has around a 20 percent stake — paid more than $422 million (306 million pounds) to resolve charges that it bribed Brazilian officials. 
While Lim did not name Keppel in his speech published on Monday, his remarks left little doubt about the firm in question and Temasek's aversion to corrupt practices. 
"What happened recently was a shock, not just to the company concerned, but it really dents the reputation of Singapore and all the other Temasek companies," Lim said. 
"In markets where practices are questionable and compromising integrity is required to win business or contracts, we have to be very clear — there is a bright red line our companies should not cross." Related Securities
